Tomato___Bacterial_spot.symptoms: Small, water-soaked leaf lesions with yellow halos, turning brown and dry. Fruits develop raised, rough spots.
Tomato___Bacterial_spot.causes: Caused by Xanthomonas spp., spread via splashing water and contaminated tools.
Tomato___Bacterial_spot.effects: Defoliation, fruit blemishes, and lower marketability.

cultural: Avoid working in fields when wet

chemical.note: Apply every 7–10 days during humid conditions

Tomato___Early_blight.symptoms: Dark spots with concentric rings on older leaves, surrounded by yellow zones.
Tomato___Early_blight.causes: Alternaria solani fungus, favored by warm, humid conditions.
Tomato___Early_blight.effects: Leaf loss, reduced photosynthesis, and smaller fruit yield.

chemical.note: Apply as soon as symptoms appear

Tomato___Late_blight.symptoms: Large, irregular, water-soaked lesions with pale green borders; white mold under leaf.
Tomato___Late_blight.causes: Phytophthora infestans oomycete; thrives in cool, wet conditions.
Tomato___Late_blight.effects: Leaf and fruit rot, total crop failure if untreated.

chemical.note: Start preventive sprays before rainy season

Tomato___Leaf_Mold.symptoms: Yellow spots on upper leaf surfaces and olive-green to gray mold on the undersides.
Tomato___Leaf_Mold.causes: Fungus Fulvia fulva, spread in humid, poorly ventilated environments.
Tomato___Leaf_Mold.effects: Reduces leaf area and photosynthesis; weakens plants.

chemical.note: Apply at first sign of disease

Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.symptoms: Small, circular spots with gray centers and dark brown margins, mainly on lower leaves.
Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.causes: Fungus Septoria lycopersici, spreads in humid conditions through splashing water or debris.
Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.effects: Premature defoliation, reduced yield due to decreased photosynthesis.

chemical.note: Start application at first symptom appearance

Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider.symptoms: Stippling or tiny yellow spots on leaves; fine webbing under heavy infestations.
Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider.causes: Infestation by two-spotted spider mites (Tetranychus urticae), favored by hot, dry conditions.
Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider.effects: Leaf bronzing, drop, stunted plant growth, reduced yield.

cultural: Spray plants with water to knock off mites

chemical.note: Use selective miticides to avoid harming beneficial insects

Tomato___Target_Spot.symptoms: Dark brown spots with concentric rings (bullseye pattern) on leaves and fruits.
Tomato___Target_Spot.causes: Fungus Corynespora cassiicola, spread through water and infected plant debris.
Tomato___Target_Spot.effects: Leaf drop and fruit lesions, leading to poor fruit quality and lower yield.

chemical.note: Begin treatment early when spotting appears

Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.symptoms: Upward curling and yellowing of leaves, stunted growth, flower drop.
Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.causes: Transmitted by whiteflies carrying Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus (TYLCV).
Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.effects: Severely stunted plants with little or no fruit; major economic losses.

cultural: Control whiteflies with yellow sticky traps

chemical.note: Apply systemically early in the season

Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.symptoms: Mottled or mosaic-like light and dark green areas on leaves, sometimes with leaf distortion.
Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.causes: Caused by Tomato Mosaic Virus (ToMV), spread through contact with infected tools, hands, or plants.
Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.effects: Reduced plant vigor, deformed fruits, uneven ripening, and lower yields.

Tomato___healthy.recommendations: Tomato plant is healthy. Maintain clean fields and seed health.
monitoring_advice: Inspect leaves for dark lesions weekly
Apply fungicide preventively if wet conditions persist
